item.title: One million permanent humanitarian visas: Calls for change as milestone nears
item.description: While advocates celebrate Australia's one millionth permanent humanitarian visa, experts also say Australia needs to reassess its approach.

item.title: 'We now have a group chat': How five single mothers came together to reveal a love scam
item.description: A group of Chinese Australian single mothers were shocked to discover they'd all dated the same man — in some cases at the same time.

item.title: Israel confirms remains returned are soldier Hadar Goldin killed in Gaza in 2014
item.description: Israeli authorities have received the remains of a hostage which Hamas says is the body of an Israeli soldier who was killed in 2014 and held for 11 years.

item.title: 'It shouldn't be painful to be a woman': Victorian report lays bare health care battle
item.description: The Victorian government has released the final report of an inquiry into women's experiences of pain - and it's made for some uncomfortable reading. Shaped by the experiences of 13,000 women and girls, the report has revealed gender health gaps, experiences of medical bias, sexism and misogyny, and feelings of being ignored or dismissed by clinicians are rampant throughout the Victorian health system.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 10 November 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Hopes of end to US shutdown lifts markets; ANZ profit slump
item.description: Growing optimism that the US government shutdown could end this week has lifted share markets, including the ASX-200. Plus, ANZ has reported a full-year cash profit of $5.8 billion, down by 14 per cent after factoring in legal penalties and the costs of mass redundancies. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Mathan Somasundaram, CEO of Deep Data Analytics.

item.title: INTERVIEW: BBC is facing an orchestrated campaign to undercut public trust says analyst
item.description: The director for the International Centre for Journalists says the resignation of two senior figures at the BBC is a result of an "orchestrated campaign to undercut public trust" in the broadcaster. The head of the BBC, director-general Tim Davie and news CEO Deborah Turness both resigned after criticism of the broadcaster’s editing of a speech by US President Donald Trump. Critics said the way the speech was edited for the BBC's flagship documentary program Panorama last year was misleading and cut out a section where Donald Trump said that he wanted supporters to demonstrate peacefully. Mr Trump has threatened legal action against the BBC over the way the speech he made was edited. Julie Posetti is a professor of journalism at City St George's University of London and director for the International Centre for Journalists and she's speaking here to AP.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 11 November 2025
item.description: A five minute bulletin for English Language learners

item.title: Why consumers are optimistic despite inflation & CBA Q2 profit rises 2%
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Westpac's Matt Hassan about a dramatic rise in consumer confidence, despite reaccelerating inflation and diminishing prospects of lower interest rates; plus the day on the sharemarket with Jamie Hannah from VanEck, including a closer look at the Commonwealth Bank's latest profit result.

item.title: 'You could die, make a will': Australia's fresh warning amid 'dark' travel trend
item.description: Australians have been kidnapped, detained and targeted by terror attacks in this central Asian country, Smartraveller warns.

item.title: The Dismissal: how it all played out
item.description: On November 11, 1975, Australia experienced its most dramatic constitutional crisis when Governor-General Sir John Kerr dismissed Prime Minister Gough Whitlam 50 years ago. We examine the full story of the Dismissal, from the political deadlock and the Loans Affair to Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's recent claim of a "partisan political ambush" and new evidence suggesting foreign interference.

item.title: The 'incredibly toxic' hidden ingredient experts want banned from our supermarkets
item.description: Researchers analysed 28,000 products stocked in Australian supermarkets. Here's what they found.

item.title: Is your blocked nose a sign of hay fever or a cold? Here's what to know
item.description: Duration and triggers for symptoms can provide clues.

item.title: 'God's not making any more land': Price gap between homes and apartments growing
item.description: On average, houses in capital cities are nearly 50 per cent more expensive than apartments. Five years ago, the gap was only 20 per cent.

item.title: Australia's dispute with Türkiye over COP31 hosting rights could see both miss out
item.description: Ethiopia will host the UN's COP32 climate summit in 2027, but next year's COP31 remains a contest between Türkiye and Australia.

item.title: Victoria to introduce 'adult time for violent crime' reform in response to rising crime
item.description: Children as young as 14 could face possible life sentences under the proposed changes to be announced by the Victorian premier on Wednesday.

item.title: At COP30, Indigenous leaders demand greater powers to protect their land.
item.description: Indigenous leaders in the Amazon are urging leaders at the UN Climate Summit to empower First Nations people to protect their land and rainforests. As world leaders gather in the Amazonian city of Belem, pressure is on to go beyond words and ideas and start implementing meaningful policy.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 12 November 2025
item.description: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

item.title: As ADHD medications cause a rise in poisonings, experts call for a key change
item.description: ADHD medication poisonings have quadrupled in the last decade, according to new data, with children most at risk of adverse exposures.

item.title: 'Punishing trauma': Experts say proposal to fix 'crime capital' could have opposite effect
item.description: Young offenders in Victoria could face life imprisonment under proposed reforms, but advocates say the move won't make communities safer.

item.title: Property investor loans at record & market sentiment bullish despite down day
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Maree Kilroy from Oxford Economics Australia about the latest home loan data which shows lending to investors hit a record high to find out what it means for supply; plus James Gerrish from Market Parters takes a look at the day's market action and reveals what he's telling his clients.

item.title: Why young, child-free men like Trent are choosing permanent contraception
item.description: Trent is among the men choosing a vasectomy, challenging ideas around contraception and rethinking having kids in a world of rising costs.

item.title: 'Demands urgent attention': Study finds widening disparities in cancer survival rates
item.description: The equity gap has swelled since four decades ago, according to analysis of data from almost one million cancer patients.

item.title: The record-breaking US shutdown has finally ended, as bill heads to Trump's desk
item.description: The House passed a spending bill that will end the longest government shutdown in US history.

item.title: The record-breaking US shutdown has finally ended, as bill heads to Trump's desk
item.description: The House passed a spending bill that will end the longest government shutdown in US history.

item.title: 'Side by side': Australia's first treaty with Aboriginal people signed into law in Victoria
item.description: Before today, Australia was one of few Commonwealth countries without any treaties in place with its First Nations peoples.

item.title: Ukraine's Zelenskyy orders ministers to quit over $100 million energy scandal
item.description: Ukraine's President, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, has called for the removal of the nation's justice and energy ministers, amid a wide-reaching corruption scandal involving the state nuclear power company. One minister has submitted her resignation, the other has been suspended. Ukraine’s anti-corruption agency has carried out a major investigation, involving alleged kickbacks worth around $100 million in the energy sector.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 13 November 2025
item.description: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

item.title: The Liberal Party has dumped net zero — but the Coalition's real battle lies ahead
item.description: Sussan Ley has held her ground as the Liberals drop their net zero pledge. But unity, and credibility on climate, remain up for grabs.

item.title: What is next for the Liberals now they have scrapped their net zero commitment?
item.description: The Liberal Party has voted to officially abandon its net zero by 2050 emissions reduction target, following a contentious internal meeting. This dramatic policy reversal, which will also seek to remove the target from the Climate Change Act, has triggered fierce internal debate among senior members and drawn criticism from the government and independents.

item.title: Philippines in tatters, Trump taps a former terrorist and, well, Bob Ross
item.description: Typhoon Fung Wong leaves a vast trail of destruction in the Philippines, Syrian President Al-Sharaa shoots hoops before meeting Trump and Trump COPs it in Brazil. Also Zelenskyy under fire from corruption allegations, why AI is spreading Russian propaganda, and Bob Ross makes a splash.

item.title: CEO Series: Xero's Sukhinder Singh Cassidy & ASX tumbles on jobs gain
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Xero CEO Sukhinder Singh Cassidy following the accounting software group's 42% rise in half-year profit to find out where growth is coming from and how it is using AI; Devika Shivadekar from RSM Australia goes through the better-than expected labour force report to explain what it means for interest rates; plus the market reaction with Zoran Kresovic from Blueberry Markets.

item.title: 'Cigars and champagne': The Netanyahu corruption case at the centre of Trump's pardon plea
item.description: The Israeli prime minister has faced a years-long trial over allegations of fraud and accepting bribes.

item.title: Historic Victorian treaty the start of a new era, Indigenous leaders say
item.description: It's been hailed as a moment centuries in the making: the signing of Australia's first ever state-wide treaty with Aboriginal people, described as something once thought impossible. The Australian-first treaty will take effect just before Christmas but will not be up and running until mid-2026. And for both sides signing the pact in Victoria, there's recognition of more hard work that needs to be done.

item.title: Australia's 'flawed' health star ratings face criticism as they hit a deadline
item.description: A deadline for Australia's contentious Health Star Rating system has arrived — and could spark big change.

item.title: How this rising star responded to men telling her she was 'too pretty to do comedy'
item.description: Elouise Eftos is used to people judging her on her appearance. With her hit debut comedy show, she's having the last laugh.

item.title: Israel identifies deceased hostage returned by Hamas
item.description: Israeli authorities say the bodies of three hostages are still being held in the Gaza Strip.

item.title: Having 'a crack': What's the go with the social media ban?
item.description: Weeks out from Australia's world-first age restrictions being implemented, there are still plenty of questions about the platforms that will fall under the ban, the ones that won't and how companies are actually going to figure out users' ages at all. This week, Elfy and Rania chat about what we know so far and how it's all reflecting on the Albanese government right now.

item.title: 'Crushing waves', not 'shore dumps': Are beach warnings failing overseas visitors?
item.description: As summer approaches and many gear up for a swim at the beach, a study suggests unclear warning signs to non-English speakers are posing risks.

item.title: BBC apologises to Donald Trump over documentary speech edit
item.description: The news organisation said, however, that it strongly disagrees that there are grounds for a defamation claim.

item.title: The mystery of Australia's deepest lake has finally been solved
item.description: A CSIRO team spent nine days on Tasmania's Lake St Clair, and they've finally answered one key question: how deep it really is.

item.title: Settler attack on a mosque sparks international condemnation
item.description: A fresh settler attack on a mosque in the occupied West Bank has drawn sharp international condemnation and intensified scrutiny of Israel’s handling of rising violence in the territory. The arson and vandalism at Deir Istiya, which left Korans burned and hate-filled graffiti on the walls, comes amid warnings from the United Nations that such assaults risk fuelling a wider regional crisis.

item.title: Hopes dashed as global fossil fuel emissions increase in 2025
item.description: For the second straight year, emissions from fossil fuels rose by slightly more than one per cent. Scientists at the COP30 climate conference in Brazil say it's one of the smallest in recent non-pandemic years - but it means efforts to curb warming global temperatures by getting fossil fuel emissions to stop rising are still not meeting targets.

item.title: ‘Popping champagne corks’: Climate change boss lashes Coalition for dumping net zero
item.description: Matt Kean said his former party is walking away from scientific evidence — and pandering to mining lobbyists.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 14 November 2025
item.description: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

item.title: What does the treaty with Indonesia actually mean?
item.description: Australia's leaders remain circumspect about the terms of a security agreement with a key northern neighbour after finalising the deal with Indonesia's president. But Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the deal commits the nations to consult regularly on matters of security, and consider possible measures should either's security be threatened.

item.title: Dementia now Australia's biggest killer, as leading causes of death revealed
item.description: Dementia deaths have risen steadily over the past decade, reflecting Australia's ageing population, according to the ABS.

item.title: 20,000 new Epstein documents just dropped. Here's what we learned
item.description: The White House criticised the Democrats' smaller document release, saying it was selectively chosen to make Trump look bad.

item.title: This film starring Rose Byrne airs the unspeakable parts of motherhood
item.description: Motherhood is often seen as an idealised, glossy experience. But this new film from Rose Byrne aims to unpack the stigma that comes with regretting having children.

item.title: How David's 'game-changing' system saves him up to $50,000 a year
item.description: Small business owner David Stuart was spending about $24,000 a year on electricity — until a solar overhaul changed everything.

item.title: April Le Sueur claims 2025 NATSI Sports Award
item.description: A young volunteer for a football club in central Victoria has won the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander (NATSI) Sports Awards this year. April Le Sueur has been volunteering at the Rumbalara Football and Netball Club in the Victorian town of Shepparton. She's also the AFL Young Leader of the Year.

item.title: As power prices surge, David has found ways to cut running costs by thousands
item.description: Rising electricity prices are a major driver of headline inflation, putting pressure on households and Australia’s 2.6 million small business owners. Some are beating the odds – here’s how.

item.title: Australia welcomes Trump's backtrack on food-import tariffs
item.description: The new exemptions mark a sharp reversal for US President Donald Trump, who has long insisted that his import duties are not fuelling inflation.

item.title: Worth up to $100k and hidden in chocolate boxes: Inside Australia's illegal animal trade
item.description: Global illegal trade in wildlife is estimated to be worth $32 billion, with rare species in Australia at risk.

item.title: New health advice issued after asbestos found in kids' play sand sold at major retailers
item.description: Regulators say the health risk is low but recommend careful disposal methods as the investigation into contaminated play sand continues.

item.title: 'The worst possible situation': This major city only has a few days of water left
item.description: Tehran's main water sources are in a dire situation, with two major dams reaching what officials are calling "dead capacity".

item.title: INTERVIEW: NITV Radio talks to Dr Harry Hobbs on Victoria's treaty becoming law
item.description: This week a treaty between Victoria and the state's First Nations people became law. Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan, First Peoples' Assembly of Victoria co-chairs Ngarra Murray and Rueben Berg signed the treaty at a formal ceremony at Government House on Thursday morning. Kerri-Lee Barry from SBS' NITV Radio has spoken with UNSW Law & Justice Associate Professor, Dr Harry Hobbs, about the historic agreement.

item.title: Zelenskyy renews calls for more air defence after deadly Russian strike on Kyiv
item.description: The death toll from Friday's attack on Kyiv had risen to seven after an elderly woman died in hospital.

item.title: Major MAGA figure says she's facing threats fuelled by Trump after split over Epstein files
item.description: Marjorie Taylor Greene was one of only four House Republicans who joined Democrats in signing a petition to force a vote on releasing the files related to Epstein.

item.title: INTERVIEW: The Great Koala Count and the citizen scientists involved
item.description: Scientists in South Australia are asking the public to help count koalas - in a citizen science initiative that could have national implications.

item.title: INTERVIEW: The Great Koala Count and the citizen scientists involved
item.description: Scientists in South Australia are asking the public to help count koalas - in a citizen science initiative that could have national implications.

item.title: Palestinians who 'mysteriously' landed in South Africa had third-country approval, Israel says
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa said it seemed like the Gazans "were being flushed out".

item.title: Thousands march in Brazil in first big UN climate protest in years
item.description: It was the first major protest outside the annual climate talks since COP26 four years ago in Glasgow.

item.title: UK Labour strips asylum seeker rights amid surging support for Nigel Farage's Reform party
item.description: Among other changes, the duty to provide support to certain asylum seekers, including housing and weekly allowances, will be revoked.

item.title: Opposition presents its plan to put power prices at the centre of climate and energy policy
item.description: After a period of internal dispute over emissions reduction targets, the Coalition has presented a climate and energy plan.

item.title: "Australia have got this": Socceroos remember World Cup qualifier against Uruguay, 20 years on
item.description: In 2005, the Socceroos defeated Uruguay in Sydney, qualifying for the FIFA World Cup for the first time in 32 years. Twenty years later, two of the men that played a key role in securing the victory have reunited to recount the night few will ever forget.

item.title: Need a new job? These are the top 10 skills Australian employers are looking for
item.description: Despite concerns about AI and job losses, there is enduring demand for uniquely human skills, new analysis suggests.

item.title: I was abandoned as a baby. I want to ask my mother why
item.description: As a newborn, Caron Michelle Brown was left on the steps of a health clinic. She's still searching for her mother — and her own identity.

item.title: Australia downplays co-hosting COP31 after Türkiye proposes sharing event
item.description: Australia and Türkiye both submitted bids in 2022 to host COP31, and neither has withdrawn, leading to an attention-sapping impasse.

item.title: Murder of anti-drug mayor sparks Gen Z protests in Mexico
item.description: More than 100 people were injured in the protests, which were sparked by the assassination of the mayor of the western city of Uruapan.

item.title: Coalition cements climate policy: no net zero, more fossil fuel as a move towards nuclear
item.description: The Coalition has formally solidified its dumping of the net zero emissions target in a party room meeting in Canberra. But it's gone much further, with the Liberals and Nationals unveiling a plan to strip climate change from the national energy regulator's list of objectives, while vowing to continue to reduce emissions by monitoring the progress of other countries.

item.title: Netanyahu voices opposition to Palestinian state ahead of UN Security Council vote on Gaza
item.description: The draft resolution would follow the US-brokered ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas and mentions a possible future Palestinian state.

item.title: 'We are heartbroken': Australian cycling mourns Paralympian gold medallist Paige Greco
item.description: The para-cyclist died in her Adelaide home on Sunday after experiencing a "sudden medical episode".

item.title: As the play sand asbestos scare continues to grow, here's what we know so far
item.description: More recalls, more Canberra school closures, and the sand has been found at over 100 sites in South Australia.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 17 November 2025
item.description: A five minute bullet in for English language learners

item.title: Three day US government shutdown ends, but investors still nervous
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with George Boubouras from K2 Asset Management Ltd about the day's market moves including how the US government shutdown will impact the US Federal Reserve's next interest rate decision, plus a preview of Nvidia's quarterly results.

item.title: 'Difficult territory': What happens if we don't reach net zero?
item.description: Failing to achieve net zero would "disproportionately" exacerbate the climate impacts projected for Australia, experts say. Here's how.

item.title: 'Gets under the skin': The disadvantage shaping the future of 950,000 Australian kids
item.description: A new report shines a light on how poverty is impacting a growing number of Australian kids.

item.title: SBS News goes one on one with Federal Opposition Leader Sussan Ley
item.description: Just days after her party ditched its support of net zero emissions targets, federal Opposition Leader Sussan Ley talks to SBS Chief Political Correspondent Anna Henderson about that policy, immigration, and more in a lengthy one on one interview.

item.title: UK cuts asylum seeker rights in major overhaul
item.description: Sweeping changes have been announced to Britain's controversial asylum system as polls show immigration has overtaken the economy as voters' top concern. The Labour government has been hardening its immigration policies as it seeks to stem the surging popularity of the populist Reform UK party, which has driven the immigration agenda and forced Labour to adopt a tougher line.

item.title: South African man's Australian visa cancelled after neo-Nazi rally outside NSW parliament
item.description: Matthew Gruter was one of the 60 demonstrators who took part in a protest touting Hitler slogans outside NSW parliament.

item.title: Ley downplays past net zero remarks, stops short of revealing personal view
item.description: The Opposition leader has said the Coalition's new energy policy proves she still has the support of the party.

item.title: Ley downplays past net zero remarks, stops short of revealing personal view
item.description: The Opposition leader has said the Coalition's new energy policy proves she still has the support of the party.

item.title: 'Not just fear': Why some Australians are sending their gold overseas
item.description: Gold prices have been glimmering, keeping buyers and sellers busy. But for some Australians, it's more than a market play.

item.title: INTERVIEW: SBS talks to Kaveh Madani on Tehran's water crisis
item.description: Kaveh Madani warned Iran about water scarcity 20 years ago. He was called a "water terrorist." Now Iran is experiencing an extreme water crisis, its like not seen for more than six decades. Tehran, famous for its surrounding snowy mountains, has had no rain in over 200 days. Its main water sources are in a dire situation; two major dams supplying the capital are at less than 10 per cent capacity. Kaveh Madani is the director of the United Nations University Institute for Water, Environment and Health, and warned of this situation back in the early 2000s, and he's speaking here to SBS broadcaster Niv Sadrolodabaee.

item.title: UK's planned overhaul of asylum system slashes key protections for refugees
item.description: The UK government has called the proposed changes the "most sweeping reforms to tackle illegal migration in modern times".

item.title: Jess Wilson promises 'clear choice' for voters as Brad Battin admits votes 'didn’t go my way'
item.description: The Kew MP makes history as the Victorian Liberals' first female leader. She was elected unopposed after Brad Battin lost the spill motion.

item.title: Jess Wilson promises 'clear choice' for voters as Brad Battin admits votes 'didn’t go my way'
item.description: The Kew MP makes history as the Victorian Liberals' first female leader. She was elected unopposed after Brad Battin lost the spill motion.

item.title: What does the Gaza plan endorsed by the UN Security Council include?
item.description: The resolution endorses US President Donald Trump's 20-point ceasefire plan, which calls for a transitional authority in Gaza.

item.title: How does your income compare? What Australians earned in a $1.3 trillion year
item.description: Most Australians get their personal income from their jobs, but investments are also growing as a source of income for many.

item.title: Bangladesh's former Prime Minister is sentenced to death
item.description: Bangladesh has entered one of its most volatile political periods in decades after former prime minister Sheikh Hasina was sentenced to death after being convicted over last year’s student-led uprising. She strongly rejects the ruling as illegitimate and politically motivated, insisting she was denied a fair trial. The verdict has heightened fears of renewed unrest, deepening political polarisation, and uncertainty over who will lead the Awami League into future elections.

item.title: 'FIFA Pass': Donald Trump announces fast-tracked visas for World Cup ticket holders
item.description: The US has promised a seamless experience for next year's tournament despite concerns that Trump's border crackdown could hurt fans.

item.title: Scammers 'love' it: The $260 million reason Aussies are urged to be on alert
item.description: Australians have lost nearly $260 million to scams this year, with shopping scams surging as sales season kicks off.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 18 November 2025
item.description: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

item.title: Asbestos contaminated play sand: more schools close
item.description: A national recall for imported coloured play sand contaminated with asbestos has expanded its impact. There are now school closures and remediation efforts across South Australia, the ACT, and Tasmania over concerns about the contamination. Experts suggest the potential for long-term harm depends on the specific type of asbestos found—and whether the sand is free-flowing enough to allow for inhalation.

item.title: 'They hate modern Australia': South African neo-Nazi detained after visa cancelled
item.description: Matthew Gruter was one of 60 black-clad demonstrators who were allowed to assemble outside NSW parliament and yell Hitler youth chants on 8 November.

item.title: Ultra conservative expected to become Chile's next president in December
item.description: Ultraconservative lawyer Jose Antonio Kast is the favourite to become Chile's next leader, when he and rival Jeanette Jarra head to a second round of presidential elections next month. Neither candidate scored a majority of votes in the first round, triggering a run-off election that is expected to be dominated by votes for Chile's conservative parties.

item.title: $60bn wiped from ASX & scams rise ahead of Black Friday sales
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with David Lane from Ord Minnett about why the ASX200 had its second worst day of the year as $60bn is wiped off the value of the local sharemarket; plus Angelica Waite discusses the rise of scams ahead of Black Friday with the ACCC's Catriona Lowe.

item.title: Campaign targets schoolies over alcohol dangers while overseas
item.description: As thousands of teenagers celebrate the end of Year 12, they're being reminded of the risks that come with drinking alcohol, especially overseas.The parents and friends of methanol-poisoning victims Bianca Jones and Holly Bowles have joined a new safety push, encouraging young travellers to make safer choices.

item.title: 'Clearly bitter': Liberal senator responds after ex-colleague's 'inept', 'lazy' claims
item.description: Liberal senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price has responded to a former colleague's claims she's being used to undermine party leader Sussan Ley.

item.title: The tiny island taking one of the world's most valuable companies to court
item.description: The people of Pari Island have contributed minimally to climate change, but rising sea levels are threatening to swallow their home.

item.title: 'Things happened': Donald Trump defends Saudi crown prince over journalist's murder
item.description: The US president gave the de facto ruler of Saudi Arabia a lavish welcome to the White House.

item.title: eSafety commissioner says Roblox age restrictions come after negotiations, fine threats
item.description: Roblox said its age-checking technology would limit inappropriate conversations between children and adults on the platform.

item.title: Trump to sign bill releasing Epstein files, White House official says
item.description: An almost unanimous vote by the US Congress to force the release of the files came days after Donald Trump abruptly reversed his opposition.

item.title: The 'quick cash' scams criminals are using to lure international students
item.description: Criminals are targeting international students with cash offers for access to their bank accounts and identity documents, police warn.

item.title: US Congress votes to force release of Epstein files
item.description: The US Congress has voted overwhelmingly to release the Department of Justice files on disgraced financier and convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. After months of political pressure to release the files, survivors of Epstein's abuse say they hope this can lead to some justice.

item.title: 'Nobody should face this hatred': NSW moves to crack down on Nazi symbols after march
item.description: The NSW government is moving to crack down on Nazi symbols, giving police new powers to act against public displays.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 19 November 2025
item.description: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

item.title: Cyclone Fina off NT's Top End intensifies into a category two storm
item.description: A weekend of heavy rain, destructive winds, felled trees and power cuts awaits the Top End as the first cyclone of the season approaches.

item.title: Socceroos lose to Colombia in New York as World Cup preparations continue
item.description: Australia took on Colombia in an international friendly in New York, following their loss against Venezuela on Saturday.

item.title: Flattery, fighter jets and a trillion dollar pledge as Saudi Crown Prince meets Trump
item.description: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, returning to the White House for the first time since the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, has met President Donald Trump at the Oval Office. The two leaders discussed a number of matters including Saudi Arabia investing a trillion US dollars in America for AI Chips, F-35 fighter jets, the Khashoggi assassination and Gaza's reconstruction.

item.title: Curaçao makes World Cup history after completing fairytale qualification campaign
item.description: Curaçao has replaced Iceland as the smallest nation by population to qualify for a World Cup.

item.title: Waste, harassment claims and walkouts: Behind a city's months-long bin workers' strike
item.description: The situation became more complicated when agency workers covering during the strike voted to take industrial action themselves.

item.title: Eyes on Nvidia & wages rise above inflation
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Matt Sherwood from Perpetual about the day's market action including why Nvidia's quarterly results tomorrow may be a turning point; plus Paula Gadsby from EY goes through the latest wages data and what it means for interest rates.

item.title: Chris Minns on hospital funding row: we can't all be wrong
item.description: State premiers have come together for an urgent meeting, as tensions rise over reaching a new public hospital funding deal with the federal government. A new report from the Grattan Institute also finds Australia's hospitals are wasting more than $1 billion a year on avoidable spending.

item.title: 'Sheer terror': Palestinians arrive in Australia after 'mysterious' South Africa flight saga
item.description: A small group of Palestinians with Australian visas were onboard a flight to South Africa making headlines around the world, and have since made their way to Australia.

item.title: Calls for superannuation protections as some retirees could lose up to $205,000
item.description: A new report is calling on the federal government to include protections for retirees when it comes to super performance testing.

item.title: 'The worst we've seen': The type of job that's getting harder to find in Australia
item.description: A new report has painted a grim picture of Australia's employment system, calling on the federal government to urgently intervene.

item.title: Children among 25 killed in Russian strike on apartment block in western Ukraine
item.description: UN human rights chief Volker Turk said he was "appalled" by the number of civilian casualties.

item.title: Trump signs off on release of Epstein files, reversing stance after months of pressure
item.description: The material could shed more light on the activities of Epstein, who socialised with Trump and other notable figures before his 2008 conviction.

item.title: Trump signs off on release of Epstein files, reversing stance after months of pressure
item.description: The material could shed more light on the activities of Epstein, who socialised with Trump and other notable figures before his 2008 conviction.

item.title: Indonesia’s drowning island takes historic climate case to court
item.description: Indonesia is home to more than 17,000 islands, but its smallest are highly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. The tiny community of Pari Island is facing multiple climate-induced threats, including to its entire existence.Four people on the island are now trying to launch a landmark legal case against a European cement giant over its historic carbon emissions.

item.title: At least 25 Palestinians killed in Israeli airstrikes across Gaza, medics say
item.description: Wednesday's strikes were among the deadliest in the territory since the ceasefire came into force.

item.title: Cyclone Fina to swing toward the Northern Territory as it holds at category two
item.description: Residents are stocking up on basic supplies as the cyclone is expected to turn south on Thursday.

item.title: 'Pushing its own agenda': PNG's top diplomat lashes Türkiye after Australia withdraws COP31 bid
item.description: Australia has abandoned its bid to host COP31 in Adelaide, meaning the event will be held in Türkiye.

item.title: Meta admits there may be mistakes as it brings teenager social media ban forward
item.description: Meta warns some teenagers may "mistakenly lose access" as it rushes to implement new social media restrictions.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 20 November 2025
item.description: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

item.title: Bicycle kicks and tears: Here are the teams who have qualified for the 2026 FIFA World Cup
item.description: In the November qualifying rounds, 14 additional teams, including some surprising names, secured their places for the 2026 FIFA World Cup.

item.title: 'Completely emptied': Human rights report alleges Israeli war crimes in West Bank camps
item.description: Human Rights Watch reports 32,000 Palestinians were forcibly displaced from West Bank camps in 2025.

item.title: Trump, Epstein & the Saudi Crown Prince, and autocrat karaoke
item.description: Trump wipes the slate clean of murder for Mohammed bin Salman because ‘things happen’. The Epstein files move a big step closer to being released and what it’s like reporting on the ground in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Plus, the comment that sent China-Japan relations plummeting.

item.title: 'Game of Thrones': NSW Opposition leader Mark Speakman resigns under party pressure
item.description: Two challengers — Vaucluse MP Kellie Sloane and former minister Alister Henskens — are gunning for Mark Speakman's position ahead of an expected leadership ballot.

item.title: Nvidia goes off the charts as ASX recovers
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Ben Clark from TMS Private Wealth to go through AI chip giant Nvidia's record results and whether this is the turning point the market was looking for.

item.title: 'Can't have it all': Australia abandons bid for COP31 climate summit
item.description: The federal government has abruptly abandoned its bid to host the United Nations climate conference next year, conceding Turkiye will oversee the COP31. The Pacific countries and environmental activists have criticised the federal government's failure to bring the event to Adelaide.

item.title: Asian-Australian awards shine — and expose the ‘Bamboo Ceiling’ above
item.description: The contributions of Asian-Australians across all levels of society have been recognised at the annual Asian-Australian Leadership Awards. This year's winners range from a year-12 graduate providing financial literacy education in developing countries, to an internationally acclaimed neurosurgeon. But the spotlight on their success has also highlighted a lack of diversity in leadership positions, known as the 'Bamboo Ceiling'.

item.title: 'Daily challenge': The hidden cost of living crisis affecting families
item.description: A food relief charity says it has so much demand it's forced to turn schools away.

item.title: PNG questions 'what planet' the Opposition is on, after it ditches net zero support
item.description: Papua New Guinea's foreign minister has said the Opposition's position on climate change "won't do them any favours, or us any favours".

item.title: Albanese's deposed attorney-general urges Labor to embrace ambitious reform
item.description: Mark Dreyfus has said "early Labor figures would be mightily disappointed" in the Labor party's track record on constitutional reform.

item.title: Europe's top diplomats discuss Ukraine peace plan | Morning News Bulletin 21 November 2025
item.description: Europe's top diplomats discuss a U-S peace deal for Ukraine,Kellie Sloane emerges as frontrunner to lead NSW Liberals after Mark Speakman steps down, Australia and England renew their Ashes rivalry as the opening Test begins in Perth.

item.title: Why government debt matters: spoiler, it’s not just Monopoly money
item.description: We know government debt is around $1 trillion, we've heard it's bad for younger generations -- but we don't really know what any of it means. This week, Elfy and Rania chat with Professor Richard Holden from the University of New South Wales about government debt and why it matters.

item.title: Fire forces evacuation of Brazil climate conference with negotiations still short of a deal
item.description: The fire has now been brought under control and 13 people have been treated for smoke inhalation, officials said.

item.title: Zelenskyy open to 'constructive' work on peace plan as Europe warns against 'capitulation'
item.description: The Ukrainian president has said he's open to "constructive, honest and prompt work" on a US-backed peace plan that's facing pushback from Europe.

item.title: Former journalist and Healthy Harold's CEO Kellie Sloane to lead NSW Liberal Party
item.description: The first-term Liberal MP has 18 months before the party contests the next state election.

item.title: Former journalist and Healthy Harold's CEO Kellie Sloane to lead NSW Liberal Party
item.description: The first-term Liberal MP has 18 months before the party contests the next state election.

item.title: Kellie Sloane elected NSW Liberals leader | Midday News Bulletin 21 November 2025
item.description: In this bulletin. Kellie Sloane elected unopposed as leader of New South Wales Liberals, no consensus on major issues, on the final days of the COP30 climate summit in Brazil. And in Rugby Union, the Wallabies turn to Carter Gordon to avert an historic European whitewash.

item.title: Potential 'severe' consequences: Why you won't be allowed to use these on some flights
item.description: Rules around power banks are increasingly tightening after a string of incidents. How do you know if yours is safe?

item.title: Warning issued over 'quick cash' scam targeting international students
item.description: An urgent warning has been issued to international students departing Australia to not sell their bank accounts and ID to criminals. The Australian Federal Police says students are offered 'quick cash' - but accepting it could see them indelibly linked to crime networks.

item.title: 'That courageous girl': Matildas coach's support for Mary Fowler after alleged racism experience
item.description: Matildas star Mary Fowler has alleged she experienced racism during her time with French club Montpellier, which has denied the allegations.

item.title: Where Kunzang's from there's no ocean. Now in Darwin, he's worried about the cyclone
item.description: The man from Bhutan has only been in the NT for three months, and says he doesn't know what to expect from Fina.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 21 November 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: 'On notice': AFP charges three for alleged threats to politicians including Anthony Albanese
item.description: The AFP has seen a 63 per cent increase in threats against parliamentarians over the last four years.

item.title: Three charged for alleged harassment of politicians | Evening News Bulletin 21 November 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, three men charged for allegedly harassing Federal politicians, in an AFP crackdown, tropical Cyclone Fina is forecast to strengthen this weekend. And in football, Matildas coach praises Mary Fowler for speaking about racism, saying she'll return for the Asian Cup.

item.title: Wieambilla police shootings 'not a terrorist act', Queensland coroner says
item.description: An inquest last year heard expert evidence that the Trains engaged in terrorism that was religiously motivated.

item.title: US rate fears trump Nvidia's better than expected result
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Lochlan Halliday from Morningstar to find out what spooked investors despite Nvidia's better than expected profit and if it's likely to last.

item.title: Residents urged to remain sheltered as Cyclone Fina closes in on Darwin | Morning Bulletin 22 November 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, Residents urged to remain sheltered as Cyclone Fina closes in on Darwin; Vladimir Putin confirms Russia has received US peace proposal for ending war in Ukraine; and in cricket, Mitchell Starc dismisses claims of Australia panic amid dramatic Ashes collapse.

item.title: 'The odds are against us': Why some Australian homeowners may never upgrade
item.description: The property ladder has changed since the COVID-19 pandemic. Data shows some homeowners may never get the chance to upgrade.

item.title: 'Crisis of identity': Why state Liberals aren't following Sussan Ley on net zero
item.description: Liberal Party leadership spills in NSW and Victoria have seen two moderate women leaders emerge.

item.title: ‘No food, no money’: Khoa was abandoned and owed $10,000 in unpaid wages. He’s not alone
item.description: As the academic year ends, thousands of international students are signing on for holiday work. But if things go wrong, experts warn that few understand their legal entitlements or how to recover unpaid wages.

item.title: Leadership spills and policy reversals: How healthy is our democracy?
item.description: With the abandonment of its net-zero policies, and leadership spills in two of Australia's largest states, the Coalition is undergoing a period of major upheaval. So what does that mean for a Westminster democracy which analysts say depends on two different political positions to succeed.

item.title: Ukraine faces 'difficult choice' on US plan to end Russia's war, Zelenskyy says
item.description: Donald Trump has given Ukraine a week to accept the proposal, which would see it cede territory, among other concessions.

item.title: Darwin escapes major damage as residents praised for heeding Cyclone Fina warnings
item.description: The storm was the strongest cyclone to approach Darwin since Tracy in 1974, but there were no reports of serious injuries or damage.

item.title: Five key moments from Trump's surprisingly warm meeting with Zohran Mamdani
item.description: After months of trading barbs, the US president and incoming New York City mayor found some unexpected common ground.

item.title: Cyclone Fina closing in on Darwin | Midday News Bulletin 22 November 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, Cyclone Fina making landfall in Top End; Gunmen in Nigeria abduct 200 students and staff from Catholic school; and in Rugby Union, Wallabies hit by fresh injury blows ahead of France Test.

item.title: Owed $10,000, Khoa was left stranded on a farm with no food or funds. He's not alone
item.description: Despite recent reforms, exploitation of migrant workers remains a serious issue in Australia, experts say.

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene quits Congress | Evening News Bulletin 22 November 2025
item.description: Tropical Cyclone Fina intensifies to a category 3 storm; Republican Marjorie Taylor Greene announces her resignation after a fallout with Donald Trump; England seizes control on day two of the Ashes.

item.title: The two words missing from the world's most important climate conference agreement
item.description: An agreement on climate action has been reached at COP30 in Brazil — but not everyone is happy with the final result.

item.title: Some world leaders make decisions while chronically sleep-deprived. Should they?
item.description: Sleep deprivation undermines our ability to think clearly. So what should we make of leaders who say they run on just a few hours?

item.title: 'You don't have the freedom to leave': The human cost of Australia's solar boom
item.description: As Australia's uptake of solar panels booms, human rights groups have raised alarm about links to Uyghur forced labour in the supply chain.

item.title: A tough night for Darwin as Cyclone Fina barrels through | Morning News Bulletin 23 November 2025
item.description: Darwin residents endure a difficult night as Cyclone Fina barrels through the Top End; Israeli strikes in Gaza kill at least 20 people; And North Melbourne powers into AFLW Grand Final after overturning a six-point deficit.

item.title: 'Isolation and shame': Australians are avoiding perinatal mental health support, new research reveals
item.description: Around one in four Australians are failing to seek support when experiencing perinatal mental health issues. Experts say the data released by the Gidget Foundation highlights a lack of awareness around signs and symptoms, and ongoing stigma around the issue.

item.title: Underground struggles: Illegal miners risk death in Morocco's forgotten coal town
item.description: In one of Morocco's impoverished coal towns, illegal miners continue to risk their lives to make ends meet. In an exclusive sit-down interview with SBS News, a photojournalist has shared the harsh realities he witnessed of the miners in Jerada. Ahead of the International Mining Congress in Morocco, experts are calling for better health and safety regulations to be implemented in the country.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Associate Professor Bassina Farbenblum
item.description: As thousands of international students prepare to take summer holiday jobs, Associate Professor Bassina Farbenblum, an expert on migrants' rights from the University of New South Wales, warns that more is needed to protect students from wage theft and abuse. She says Australia has a ‘pervasive problem’ with workplace exploitation of international students and those on temporary visas. Dr Farbenblum is speaking to SBS’s Sandra Fulloon.

item.title: New names added to migration Welcome Wall at National Maritime Museum
item.description: Two panels have been unveiled at Australia's National Maritime Museum to honour a new group of migrant families. Museum Director and CEO Ms Daryl Karp and Home Affairs Minister Tony Burke say the Monument is a celebration of the long history of migrants who have shaped modern Australia.

item.title: Fresh wave of Israeli airstrikes kills more than 20 people in Gaza
item.description: Israel and Hamas have accused each other of violating the tenuous ceasefire in Gaza multiple times over the last six weeks.

item.title: Investigation into fatal Brisbane house fire | Midday News Bulletin 23 November 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, four people fighting for life after a house fire in Brisbane, Brazil's former president Jair Bolsonaro deemed a flight risk for trying to escape arrest. And in sport, the Wallabies lose to France, ending a winless tour of Europe.

item.title: How a major MAGA figure went from Trump devotee to calling quits on Congress
item.description: Marjorie Taylor Greene announced her resignation this weekend after a dramatic falling out with the president that was months in the making.

item.title: European leaders to meet over US Ukraine plan | Evening News Bulletin 23 November 2025
item.description: A cautious return to business as usual in the Top End after Cyclone Fina; European leaders meeting in Geneva over a US plan to end the war in Ukraine; Australia crushes England in the opening test of the Ashes.

item.title: Trump signals room to negotiate Ukraine peace deal, as Rubio insists plan is US-led
item.description: The US president had given Ukraine until Thursday to approve the plan, which requires it to cede territory to Russia, cut its army and pledge never to join NATO.

item.title: A 'massive' number of wildlife die on our roads. Experts say protections are falling far short
item.description: Wildlife-safe road features remain largely optional, a “nice-to-have, not need-to-have”, the author of new research warns.

item.title: 'No way out': Vietnam flooding death toll reaches 90 as search continues for missing
item.description: Relentless rain has lashed south-central Vietnam since late October and popular holiday destinations have been hit by several rounds of flooding.

item.title: 'It's just impossible': The rental crisis pushing working families to the brink
item.description: Rental stress is at its worst levels on record, with renters in one city now spending nearly a third of their income on housing.

item.title: The law that makes me wish my daughter’s alleged murderer was still alive
item.description: A coronial inquest found Sandi Harvey's daughter was murdered. But she'll never know if the alleged killer was found guilty or not.

item.title: Ukraine peace plan talks 'productive'| Morning News Bulletin 24 November 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, US and Ukrainian officials say peace talks have been productive; the government aims to pass its environment reforms in Parliament this week; and in sport, Oscar Piastri and Lando Norris disqualified from the Las Vegas Grand Prix

item.title: A Russian 'wish list' or path to peace? The evolving plan to end Russia's war on Ukraine
item.description: Donald Trump has given Ukraine until Thursday to accept the US proposal to end Russia's war. But European leaders have now stepped in with different plans — more palatable for Ukraine.

item.title: What we know about Israel's latest strike on Hezbollah in Beirut
item.description: The strike came a week before Pope Leo was set to land in Lebanon on his first foreign trip.

item.title: What we know about Israel's latest strike on Hezbollah in Beirut
item.description: The strike came a week before Pope Leo was set to land in Lebanon on his first foreign trip.

item.title: Vietnam floods death toll reaches 90
Fifty schoolchildren escape mass kidnapping in Nigeria, but hundreds still missing
item.description: If confirmed, Friday's attack on St Mary's School would be Nigeria's worst school abduction since the kidnapping of 276 girls by Boko Haram in 2014.

item.title: 'A $96 million fiasco': BoM under pressure over website redesign cost blowout
item.description: The BoM website is one of the most popular in Australia, with millions visiting each day for their weather forecasts.

item.title: The human cost of renewables: Why Australia should build solar here
item.description: With the renewable energy transition underway in Australia, the higher than expected uptake of solar panels has human rights groups concerned about links to Uyghur forced labour in the supply chain. As Australia looks into developing its own solar panel industry, rights groups say government and industry should work to ensure the clean energy transition isn't at the cost of freedom.

item.title: What Black Friday sales shopping does to your brain, and how to stay in control
item.description: Black Friday feels like a celebration of savings, but it is also a masterclass in behavioural and brain science.

item.title: Cyclone Fina approaches northern Western Australia |Midday News Bulletin 24 November 2025
item.description: Cyclone Fina approaches communities in northern Western Australia, Pioneering Australian chef Skye Gyngell dies aged 62, India makes history, winning the inaugural Blind Women's T20 Cricket World Cup.

item.title: COP30 deal keeps humanity 'in the fight for a liveable planet': UN chief
item.description: Delegates to the COP30 summit in Brazil have reached an agreement to address still rising global emissions. The deal increases money to countries hit by climate change, but contains no explicit fossil fuel plan. The agreement has mollified some - and horrified others.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 24 November 2025
item.description: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

item.title: Ashwini's biggest concerns now will cost the country 'billions' in the future
item.description: Children are growing more anxious and worried as they age, a new report says. Failing to address their concerns is costly.

item.title: Police to resume search for missing four-year-old Gus Lamont | Evening News Bulletin 24 November 202
item.description: Gunmen and suicide bombers attack a paramilitary force headquarters in Pakistan, Police to resume search for missing four-year-old Gus Lamont, Jeeno Thitikul receives biggest winning cheque in women's golf history

item.title: 'Women have choice': Anne Aly says Pauline Hanson's burqa stunt 'unacceptable'
item.description: Multiculturalism Minister Anne Aly says Pauline Hanson aims to divide with burqa stunt, arguing women "have choice".

item.title: 'Women have choice': Anne Aly says Pauline Hanson's burqa stunt 'unacceptable'
item.description: Multiculturalism Minister Anne Aly says Pauline Hanson aims to divide with burqa stunt, arguing women "have choice".

item.title: Bureau of Meteorology weathers website storm
item.description: The Bureau of Meteorology's controversial website redesign carries a staggering 96 million dollar price tag. The cost blowout has drawn sharp criticism from both government ministers and the opposition. Federal Environment Minister Murray Watt has expressed deep concern over the massive expenditure, while Nationals Leader David Littleproud warns the public that the exorbitant cost will further erode trust in the agency.

item.title: ASX bounces back as BHP walks away from AA
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Raymond Chan from Morgans Financial Limited about the day's sharemarket action including a recovery on the ASX as the chance of a US rate cut in December swings back up and why BHP walked away from a second crack at Anglo American.

item.title: Victoria Police banned racial profiling a decade ago. Has it made a difference?
item.description: Researchers said that in 2024, Aboriginal people were 15 times more likely to be searched by Victoria Police than white people.
